title: Configuring Light/Staging the Social: Dialogues between the social sciences and lighting practices
abstractText:
Configuring Light is a three year seminar series to develop a broad research agenda on the many different dimensions of light and lighting, including their significance for architecture and built space, urban planning and design, impacts on environmental sustainability, climate change and economic and ecological costs, well-being and risk and safety. The series aims to build dialogues and research networks that are international and interdisciplinary, that connect academics and practitioners and that bridge divides between social sciences, humanities and design.

 

The premise of this programme is that light is a material through which people organize social space, constituting light as an infrastructure of everyday modern life and interaction. At the same time lighting design and technology are a rapidly developing field through which central issues of built space are being rendered visible and often controversial. This seminar series therefore affords a first opportunity to develop social science methodologies, perspectives, knowledges and theories in relation to a central feature of everyday life and the technical, regulatory and design practices through which it is configured.
organisation: London School of Economics & Pol Sci
